body: @piiswrong @mli  I have finished it, Pls review

I agree, it is not feasible to keep updating everytime a new AMI is made
available. As far as I know there is no other straight forward way other
than to make it a user defined parameter and ask to the user to pickup the
AMI-Ids from S3 file which will always contain the latest AMI ids.
I think we can also make a AWS Lambda Function return the AMI-Id given a
region, I will explore that further.

Thanks for your patience.

-Naveen

On Mon, Nov 14, 2016 at 10:32 AM, Eric Junyuan Xie <notifications@github.com

> wrote:
> 
> we need a better solution than updating code everytime ...
>

改成  VarsInfo({0.1f, 0.1f, 0.2f, 0.2f}

Edit config.mk to make sure usecudapath point to cuda8.0 then rebuild

> LD_LIBRARY_PATH is
> echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH

add the path to CUDA library to link and compile flag  
if you have already add them to environment variable, leave it as NONE
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda-8.0
My config.mk file /usr/local/cuda-8.0,i checked it again. There was no error when i rebuild the whole project. I'm not sure if there was any other configure file i should modify. Thank you. @piiswrong
Could you confirm if the fix works? Would you like to submit a fix?
This error existed in mxnet-ssd branch. I have tested. Could you tell me how to submit a fix ?
i run csviter on cpu, and i come across the same problem. sometime, it can run, sometime it fail to run.
you may update your gcc to new version. I met the problem with vs2013 ctp.

@sxjscience After reading `sample_op.h` I have some idea on how to continue for a CPU version (something logic like `numpy.searchsorted(numpy.cumsum(prob), rng.rand())` as you mentioned) . But I'm not sure how to continue on for GPU version. More precisely, I don't know how to integrate cuda kernel api to **sample in parallel within a mini-batch**. Could you offer some direction on how to directly use cuda kernel (calling a function with `__device__` qualifier) in `Forward`, `Backward` function? Or there is some other approaches?
@WarBean You can directly call cuda kernels in the forward & backward functions. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/roi_pooling.cu is one example.
@sxjscience Exactly what I need. I will try it.

It seems that I did not have Rtools installed.  So I installed it and tried again.  I was unable to capture all of the error messages because of the buffer size for the command prompt window, but the tail end of the messages are given below.  I ran the command again but the second time it exited quickly with an error which can be seen at the bottom.

c:\Downloads\Mxnet\mxnet>
Hi, @piiswrong . I don't know why the check of `default`  always be failed. I have checked it by myself and I can't found the reason. Could you help me with it ?

This is related to the vector initialization, seems like some compiler are complaining about it.
DMLC_DECLARE_FIELD(variances).set_default(VarsInfo({0.1f, 0.1f, 0.2f, 0.2f})) should fix it.
I will submit a PR to solve it.

Hi @pluskid , I have the same problem (not this network, but resnet for cifar10), after change my learning rate to 0.0005, the performance turns good indeed. I'm curious about why this happened, could you give a brief explanation?
@piiswrong Is C++ 11 style initialization allowed in XXXOpParam ? Otherwise I have to change it.

My best guess is that there might be some unintentional internal changes (e.g. default optimizer parameters) or gradient rescaling according to batch size or some non-standard processing procedures that you might accidentally used that caused this problem. I think currently it is good time to re-run all the examples to make sure they are producing the expected results. Ref #3791
I see... thank you for the explanation! @pluskid
Submitted PR - https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3834
Please fix lint
@precedenceguo
It should be. But gcc 4.8 and 4.9 seem to have different level of error threshold

https://github.com/tornadomeet/ResNet

@tornadomeet Let's merge this into master

This is all running in CPU, and I'm pretty sure I tried explicitly specifying the CPU context and it didn't help.  

... and of course the current code isn't showing the bug.  I can pull up the older version of the code where it was failing.

Code is here: https://github.com/leopd/mxnet/blob/issue-3813/example/issue-3813.py

Reading the [environment variable docs](http://mxnet.io/how_to/env_var.html) I found that setting `MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE` to `NaiveEngine` seems to fix the problem.  And unsurprisingly for a race-condition, it doesn't repro reliably.  Sometimes it fails, sometimes it doesn't.  In fact once I set to NaiveEngine and it starts to work, I haven't seen it fail again on that machine.

I somehow did it. All the steps and tricks are listed below (except for ones described in [the instruction](http://mxnet.io/get_started/setup.html#installing-mxnet-on-a-gpu)):
1. Download the master branch zip file and pre-built package of THE SAME date. Now it is 20160531 - date of the latest stable release. So I have "mxnet-20160531.zip" and "20160531_win10_x64_gpu".7z files to work. If you have one of them newer you could run into troubles.
2. Place libmxnet.dll not in the "nocudnn/lib" directory but just in "libs" directory with other 11 libraries.
3. Install Rtools if you didn't it before. If you have Rtools 3.3 or 3.4 downgrade to Rtools 3.2. I personally totaly removed Rtools 3.4 and install Rtools 3.2 from scratch.
4. Add to the system PATH not only R itself but Rtools as well. For me it is "C:\Rtools\bin" and "C:\Rtools\gcc-4.6.3\bin". You can do it with installation of Rtools but it is not set by default.
5. Correct Makeconf file at "%R_HOME%\etc\x64" if you have there new compiler (not gcc-4.6.3) written. I edited 19 and 20 lines so I have now
   
   > BINPREF ?= C:/Rtools/gcc-4.6.3/bin/
   > COMPILED_BY = gcc-4.6.3
6. Run `R CMD INSTALL --no-multiarch R-package` at least!

UPD. 7. If you have (unsuccesfull) buildings before: remove "R-package" directory and repeat all the steps listed in the instruction and above. The reason is some files are already builded in the wrong way (executor.o etc.) and they are not rebuilded by default. Maybe you can just remove all this wrongly builded files but I'm not sure which files to remove and which not.

It helped me so it can help you.
Now I should try how (and if) MXNet works...
How can I see the linter errors?  The link to the failed test http://54.84.234.35:8080/job/mxnet/399/ times out for me.
#3840 Submitted, should fix it.

had similar issue on El Capitan and CUDA 8.0. adding the following string to ADD_LDFLAGS would fix it: **-F/Library/Frameworks -Xlinker -framework -Xlinker CUDA**
please see also the following issue describing fix for similar problem.
https://github.com/arrayfire/arrayfire/issues/1496

we don't put binaries (like pdf) in the repo.
Please upload them to dmlc/web-data

I see, will do, thanks.

One downside: linking to the raw github content will download the PDF rather than allowing the user to view it in the browser, and linking directly to git repo is slow. I can't seem to find an easy way to host the pdf on git and have it viewable in the browser, so I'll link to the raw github content.
Please rebase and resolve conflict
Sent a PR to web-data for this: https://github.com/dmlc/web-data/pull/8
Figured out my networking issue accessing the Jenkins server.

Fetch upstream again and rebase should fix it. Some links have been fixed which caused the 
 check to fail.

Updated:
I may have used a wrong version before. Multi-gpus for e2e training seems ok.

Original:
Yes, the e2e code in the example does not support multiple gpu training yet. We are working on that but you are welcome to contribute.
but i 'm always using multi-gpus for  e2e training.  @Trangle do you change the training symbol?
Rebased and merged conflicts.
@tornadomeet symbol was original version, and i changed the max_label_shape list，it works in multi-gpu，but really slower than just one device
@precedenceguo @tornadomeet
@tornadomeet , I  encountered the same problem and had no change for the source code.  I want to kown how you run the program using mutil-GPUs.

Pls review it again!

ameshkoff thanks for the info.
The instructions only mention "/mxnet/R-package".  I am not able to find "mxnet-20160531.zip" that you are talking about.  Where did you get this file from?
@xlvector
Is this the same as dmlc/mxnet-deepmark
I think the only lint errors remaining are the same 14 warnings that were there before.

@robert604 Go to the [Releases page](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases) and download "Source code (zip)" file from "windows binary build 20160531" area. It is the snapshot of master branch 2016-05-31 or something like this I believe.

We do not have a lot of issues with python3 so far, and most of them could get around by using the helper functions defined in the _base.py

So let us see what are the functions that are get needed, if they are indeed helpful, we can always bring it in, or write a wrapper of ours

I might add a helper in `_base.py` next time I need something.  Thanks for the pointer.

I hit the fact that py3 doesn't have `dict.iteritems()` any more.  They both have `dict.items()` which works fine, but in py2 is slow for large dictionaries since it materializes the list.  But most of our dictionaries are config not data, so they're not big.
